claim.statement: Lower‐caste households earn substantially higher agricultural income in villages where lower castes are dominant because intra-caste trade in groundwater irrigation works more efficiently, whereas cross-caste trade in upper-caste dominated villages breaks down.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Conclusion sections of the original paper (pages 1–2 and 25–26)

data.source: UP–Bihar Living Standards Measurement Study (LSMS) World Bank Village and Household Questionnaires, 1997–1998; supplemented with 2001 Indian Population Census village statistics
data.wave_or_subset: Single survey wave 1997–1998 covering 120 villages; census tables for year 2001
data.notes: Historical caste composition verified with 1921 census; study treats caste dominance as exogenous and time-invariant.

method.description: The authors compare household agricultural outcomes across villages that are dominated by upper castes versus those dominated by lower Backward Agricultural Castes (BACs). Using survey and census data, they estimate Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) regressions and Instrumental Variables (IV) models to identify the effect of village caste dominance and groundwater-market participation on farm income and yields, controlling for land quality and other household characteristics.
steps: Classify each of the 120 villages as upper-caste dominated or BAC-dominated using historical land-ownership records and caste shares.
Merge household-level LSMS data on income, crop yields, irrigation practices, and demographics.
Construct key variables: indicator for lower-caste household, indicator for BAC-dominated village, water-buyer status, and interaction terms.
Estimate OLS regressions of household crop income and yields on BAC-village indicator and its interaction with water-buyer status, controlling for household and village covariates.
Address endogeneity of groundwater access with IV regressions using village natural-water availability and total cultivated area as instruments.
Conduct robustness checks for land quality, geographic distance, tenancy, credit, and alternative irrigation sources.
Interpret coefficients and test statistical significance to draw conclusions about caste dominance and water-market efficiency.
method.models: Linear regression (OLS); Instrumental Variables (two-stage least squares)
method.independent_variables: BAC-dominated village indicator; water-buyer status; interaction (BAC × water buyer)
method.control_variables: Household land size and value, literacy, access to tubewell, village infrastructure indicators, environmental factors

results.summary: Lower-caste households realize markedly higher crop income and yields in BAC-dominated villages than in upper-caste dominated villages. The gains are strongest for households that buy irrigation water, indicating that intra-caste groundwater trade mitigates enforcement problems that hinder cross-caste transactions. IV estimates confirm that improved irrigation access, rather than land quality, drives the income differential.
